title: Fortnite blackout: Mum catches sweet reaction of boy, 7, to implosion of game's universe

A mum caught the moment her adorable boy witnessed his beloved virtual universe implode.

Yesterday evening six million people tuned in to witness a live stream event of video game Fortnite - marking the end of Season 10.

The romping shoot-em-up took an unlikely turn when a cut scene of its usually bright island of upbeat characters was sucked into a blackhole.

Since the last shreds of light disappeared into the abyss, the immensely popular online game has been out of action for the millions of Fortnite devotees.

One such fan is Maxx Honhold, whose mum Emma Broughton recorded a video of him watching the virtual world disintergrate.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

(Image: Mirrorpix)

The clip shows the seven-year-old wearing a set of alien spacecraft pyjamas and hopping around excitedly as the clip begins on the family television.

"It's going out," Maxx exclaims, clasping his hands to his head as an eerie dusk falls over Fortnite land.

"Oh my god!"

The excitement is momentarily matched by Maxx's dad Tristian, who gasps as one of the characters is blasted away from the ground.

While the gun toting figure rises up and up the young boy's excitement muffles his words.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

(Image: Mirrorpix)

As the island finally recedes into a tiny speck of light Maxx exclaims: "It's the end of Fortnite."

Mum Emma explained how much Maxx enjoys playing the game.

"He absolutely loves Fortnite and plays it with his friends once he's done his homework every evening," the Shoreham-by-Sea, Sussex woman said.

"He probably plays one hour each evening - as long as he's good."

Watching his favourite game turn to black came as a bit of a shock to Maxx, who has a three-year-old brother Louie.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

(Image: Mirrorpix)

Emma added: "Once the game wouldn't turn back on he genuinely thought it was the end of the game forever.

"He still keeps making me check online every so often for updates

"I wouldn't say he's sad, not yet anyway. He knows it will be back soon. I don't think anything could make him upset, he's such a happy child."

Unlike Maxx a lot of children have been upset by the Fortnite shutdown.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

(Image: Mirrorpix)

Another mum, Anna Harper said her 13-year-old, who has autism, plays the game everyday.

"He had a timer set on his phone for the big event yesterday and we had to be in to see it," Anna said.

"Then this happened and he refused to go to bed because the big event wasn't finished. He just wanted to watch the black hole all night in case it came back on.

"He came home from school today and has been logged in all afternoon watching to see if it changes.

"He is very worried that it will disappear forever. It would be useful to have a bit of information as to why or when so I can try to explain it to him."

It is not known when or if the game will be back online.
description: EXCLUSIVE Maxx Honhold watched as his beloved video game was reduced to a black screen, with some predicting the Season 10 event could mark the beginning of a Fortnite Chapter 2
